title: Theory of Truncation Resonances in Continuum Rod-based Phononic Crystals with Generally Asymmetric Unit Cells. (arXiv:2211.01423v1 [physics.app-ph])
description: Phononic crystals exhibit Bragg bandgaps, frequency regions within which wave propagation is forbidden. In solid continua, such bandgaps are the outcome of destructive interferences resulting from periodically alternating layers. Under certain conditions, natural frequencies emerge within these bandgaps in the form of high-amplitude localized vibrations near one boundary of the structure. In this paper, we investigate the vibrational spectrum of finite phononic crystals which take the form a one-dimensional rod, and explain the fundamental factors that contribute to the origination of truncation resonances. By identifying a unit cell symmetry parameter, we define a family of finite phononic rods which share the same unit cell dispersion relation, yet distinct truncated forms. A transfer matrix method is utilized to derive closed-form expressions of the characteristic equations governing the natural frequencies of the finite system and decipher the truncation resonances emerging across different boundary conditions. The presented analysis establishes concrete connections between the localized vibrations associated with a truncation resonance, the corresponding boundary condition, and the overall configuration of the truncated chain as dictated by the unit cell choice. The study provides tools to predict, tune, and selectively design truncation resonances, to meet the demands of various applications that require such truncation resonances.
